bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to James E. West, June 11, 1919

div1.p: Carter writes that he would appreciate the Boy Scouts' help for malaria control.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to James E. West, June 11, 1919
div1.opener:
Misscl.
Boy Scouts -
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.,
June 11, 1919.
Mr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive,
Headquarters National Council,
Boy Scouts of America,
The Fifth Avenue Building,
New York City, N. Y.
My Dear Mr. West:
div1.p: Thank you for your note of yesterday and for the enclosure.

It is very good to think that the Boy Scouts, with the co-
operation of National Headquarters, are now ready to help the U. S.
Public Health Service in its field work.

I wonder might I set you right on a few points in your bio-
graphy of General Gorgas and in Reed's experiments on the convey-
ance of yellow fever?

The experiments by which the mosquito conveyance of yellow fever
was demonstrated were made at Quemados, Cuba (1900)--not at New
Orleans. There were no deaths from these experiments, although one
man, a Spaniard, died from a similar experiment made the next year
(by Ross and Guiteras).

Gorgas did not go to Panama with the rank of Surgeon-General.
He was Colonel, however, having been advanced two grades by Special
Act of Congress, as a well deserved reward for his Havana work.
He was appointed Surgeon General in 1914 and advanced to Major Gen-
eral--also by Special Act of Congress--being the first Surgeon
General to hold that grade.

I am afraid that the page on Malaria will convey information
of less value for the control of malaria than if you had figured
and described the larvae of the malarial mosquito. Unless the
Scouts recognize the larvae, which is easy, they will not know
what waters are breeding them and hence which waters to treat.
If you so wish, you can remedy this by adding to your bibliography
Supplement No. 18, to the Public Health Reports --------- .10cts.
This brochure--to be had from the Government Printing Office, Wash-
ington, D. C.--gives considerable information on malaria.

With the very best of good wishes for Boy Scout Week, and once
more expressing my gratification that you have placed your National
organization on rapport with the Service, believe me.
